Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Advances in Esophageal Cancer Management

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured through sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from multiple centers, with eligibility criteria including confirmed EC diagnosis.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either standard care or an enhanced multimodality therapy, including surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and immunotherapy.

Objective.evidence: The study aimed to assess the impact of multimodality therapy on EC outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was overall survival, measured over a 5-year period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured through sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant improvement in overall survival (hazard ratio = 0.75, 95% CI 0.60 to 0.95; p = 0.02).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 5% of the intervention group and 3% of the control group, with mild severity.
